content.title: Unit 1: Accounting Concepts
content.subtitle: Detailed understanding of core accounting principles.

details.subtopic: Accrual vs. Cash Basis of Accounting
details.description: Advanced accounting introduces accrual accounting, recognizing revenue when earned and expenses when incurred, providing a more accurate financial picture than cash basis.
Combines financial data of parent companies and subsidiaries to reflect the overall financial health of a corporate group.
Separate accounting records for branches to track their performance and reconcile with the main office accounts.
Differentiates between operating leases (rentals) and finance leases (similar to buying on credit), affecting how leases appear in financial statements.
Covers valuation, amortization, and impairment of non-physical assets like brands and patents.
Methods like FIFO, LIFO, and weighted average cost impact financial statements significantly.
Details cash inflows and outflows from operating, investing, and financing activities.
Indicates company profitability by calculating the profit attributable to each outstanding share of common stock.
Deals with mergers, acquisitions, goodwill, and impairment testing.
Covers profit-sharing ratios, partner capital accounts, and the dissolution process of partnerships.

content.title: Unit 2: Accounting Conventions
content.subtitle: Established principles ensuring consistency and reliability in financial reporting.

details.description: Assumes a business will operate in the foreseeable future, impacting asset valuation.
Aligns expenses with revenues of the same period for accurate profitability.
Uses a single currency for financial reporting to ensure clarity and comparability.
Recognizes revenue and expenses when they occur, not when cash is exchanged.
Requires the use of consistent accounting methods for better comparison over time.
Focuses on disclosing only material information to avoid unnecessary details.
Mandates transparency by disclosing relevant financial information.
Prefers a cautious approach in uncertain situations to avoid overstating financial health.

content.title: Unit 3: Postulates and Accounting Standards
content.subtitle: Foundational assumptions and guidelines for uniformity.

details.description: Includes going concern, monetary unit assumption, and accrual accounting.
Detailed guidelines like IFRS and GAAP that ensure comparability, reduce subjectivity, and align with regulatory requirements.

details.description: Promotes clear, comparable financial statements across countries.

Covers methods like FIFO and LIFO for inventory accounting.
Guidelines for tangible assets, including depreciation and valuation.
